label: Letter from Stephen Drayton to Benjamin Lincoln
description: Letter from Stephen Drayton to Benjamin Lincoln mentioning the misconduct of the North Carolina’s commissary and continue to discuss ideas on better transportation of troops and supplies. Drayton goes on to detail some of the supplies which he has sent to various units and camps; tents, knapsacks, kettles, canteens, hoes, axes, and carpenters tools. He laments the lack of spades or shovels and states that he has enclosed a list of items.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[Stephen Drayton to Benjamin Lincoln
January 18, 1779
[RvW Box 1 Folder 24; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Charles Town [Charleston] 18th.. January 1779
Sir
Late on yesterday I had the honor of your letter
of the 12th Instant from Purysburgh. I am glad you mean to
order some of the Waggons [sic] from Camp as we are really puzzled 
to procure a sufficiency. –
I beg leave before I quit this head to mention to you
Sir, the impropriety of the Commissary of North Carolina's
conduct, in having authority to get Waggons without my
knowledge – Consequently I have several times been imposed
upon by the subterfuge of No Carolina Service, the authority
he acts under is his appointment of Commissary – which in his
State gave him ample power, but I humbly conceive can in
noway operate here - [and] even there, it must have militated
with order. -
Willing, Sir, to render every Service to my Country I can,
Forgive me, if I mention to you difficulties or improprieties that
I may meet with; hitherto, [and] for very good reasons, matters in
my Department have been carryed [sic] on without any regularity
- hence arises the many difficulties [and] the continuation of Im-
-proprieties – to lay them before you, is to remove them – In this
opinion therefore I conceive it my Duty to acquaint you of every
mode that may strike me, by which we can with more celerity 
[and] can convey Stores [and] other essentials to Camp.
with
[End Page 1]
with deference sir, let me then recommend a proper
convoy of Batteans [sic], to go from hence to Combahe [Combahee] or as circum
-stances may render it necessary to Ashepo [Ashepoo] – In doing this I
would humbly propose to get a couple of Boats on whom can
be mounted two 6 pounders in prow, a few swivels, with 
15 or 20 men each, [[and] those Militia] – such Boats can with
care be had, as Convoys, - in one fleet we can transport as
much provisions [and] other Stores as 150 or 200 Waggons could take
in – then please consider the Land carriage is Short'ned near
two thirds, [and] that two thirds some of the worst Roads. Ten
Batteans containing 70 or 80 bls. of Beef, pork or flour [and]
navigated from 4 to 6 hands can make a trip to [and] from
either of those places once in ten days upon an Average.
To sett aside the difference of Expence [sic], it would be the
means of having your Army while at their present Port, better
[and] more regularly Supplyed [sic] – from what I have said you 
can form a judgement [sic] – therefore will not intrude more upon
your time.
I have supplyed Genl. [General] Ash with a few Tents [and] knap-
-sacks, the former a few indeed – as I cannot obtain an Exem
-ption from Militia Duty for those so necessarily engaged in pub
-lic work – for want of wire I cannot send on any Kettles –
but
[End Page 2]
but in a few days shall send a large supply of Canteens - [and] my
utmost shall be exected [executed] to procure some Iron Rods to be drawn
for compleating [sic] the Kettles - spades or shovels it is in vain to hope 
for the President denies he has any, [and] not one to be bought, the
President recommends pressing them from plantations. –
Hoes, axes, [and] a few grubbing hoes I now forward – the Carpenters Tools
I shall dispatch immediately it is but within these few days I could
obtain many of the articles.
As to Carpenters I fear sir, there will be a difficulty
attending the procuring of them – never the less I will stride to
bring a company on with me.
I take Liberty to inclose [sic] a list of Articles now come
on – and have the Honor to be
Sir,
with the greatest Esteem
Your most Obedient
Humble servant
Step: [Stephen] Drayton
[ink blot]
[End Page 3]
[Addressed:]  On Public Service
The Honble [Honorable]
Major Genl. [General] Lincoln
Commander in Chief of the
Sothern Department
Camp at Purysburg
[Endorsed:] From Co. [Colonel] Drayton
Jan.y [January] 18.1779
[seal]
[End Page 4]
